title: Let the northern lights come to you as you relax at ION Hotel
text:
Let the northern lights come to you as you relax at ION Hotel Let the northern lights come to you as you relax at ION Hotel CROWDS chasing the northern lights are quick to rush to popular spots like Þingvellir, Hvalfjörður, and Grótta. PUBLISHED: 21:38, Mon, Jul 6, 2015 | UPDATED: 21:48, Mon, Jul 6, 2015 PH The Northern Lights are crystal clear on a good day 
But they should preserve their energy and leisurely head over to ION Hotel – it's one of the best spots you can view the twisted greenish streaks that light up the sky. 
And the natural phenomenon is even better seen in your bathing suit from the 10m outdoor naturally-heated dipping pool under the hotel. 
The eco-friendly hotel is situated on Mount Hengill just outside Þingvellir National Park close to where the North American and Eurasian plates meet. 
Builders had to use materials seven times the strength of those used in Reykjavik because of the boiling waters just 25ft underground. 
Once the home to the workers at the Nesjavellir geothermal power station, it's now transformed into a cool 45-room hotel . 
As ION is surrounded by natural hot springs, it provides geothermal hot water and energy to the hotel's own natural outdoor pool. 
The sheer location of the building further helps to exploit Iceland's natural beauty from all four corners. 
The Northern Lights Bar – with it's floor-to-ceiling windows on three sides – make it an ideal vantage point for watching the aurora borealis with a refreshing drink in hand. 
The spirit of Iceland is embodied throughout the hotel. Inside lava, Icelandic wool, reworked wood, recycled cardboard are all used to furnish rooms. 
Perhaps one of the most fascinating use of materials is the rubber tyre turned washroom sink. PH The bar offers fantastic views of the landscape 
In keeping with the island's emphasis on preserving its natural beauty, bathroom products are made from Icelandic herbs while bed linen and the restaurant is organic and fair trade. 
Speaking of which the restaurant is aiming to be Iceland's first with a Michelin star. 
Delicacies such as reindeer, locally caught Arctic char and skyr – homemade yoghurt – smoked bone marrow ice-cream are crafted by dedicated chefs for hours but can polished off in minutes. 
Guests are offered a range activities from horse riding in mountains around Oflus, Sólheimajökull glacier tours, rafting, hot spring hikes and even the chance to experience the tectonic plates up close through snorkelling and diving trips to Silfra. 
The less active can opt for sightseeing excursions such as the Golden Circle. 
This includes the waterfall Gullfoss and the geothermally active valley of Haukadalur, containing the Strokkur geyser – erupting every five to 10 minutes wowing crowds. 
Owner Sigurlaug Sverrisdóttir, who was born and raised in the region said the Northern Lights never get old. 
"This respect for Mother Nature is in our blood; our parents and grandparents certainly knew not to mess with her.," she said. 
'I still feel amazed when I see the Northern Lights dancing in the sky on one of my late returns from work. 
"Even though you have experienced it several times before it is different when you are outside of the city, it's much more intense."
